The transcription and encoding of these materials has been undertaken with the kind permission of Jamie Murphy, who imprint The Salvage Press, published the original printed editions of Town in 2018.

lg.l: Sailors, soldiers, gambling sons,
turn your pockets out for Mrs Mack
or to the quays you will go back
from kips and flash-rooms, alleyways.
Royal men or Leopold,
come this way to World's End Lane,
be you lonely, ill, insane.
The Nighttown workers lie in wait
as the Monto babies shriek
for sucks of milk.
The heat is that of hell's own fire.
Secret-keepers, sinners, liars —
ignore the 'poor unfortunates'.
These are the lost of Mabbot Lane.
Say nothing more of Honour Bright,
she who got the doctor riled,
wound up in the Dublin hills
(the doctor didn't giver her pills),
the policeman didn't bring her home.
A single bullet through the heart.
Soon her name on a shining plaque
will mark the Monto in the earth.
Hear the Marys, a close is near,
the women locked up in the wards
or cleaning sheets for holy men
or smothered in a sick-house bed.
Lust and porter cheap as dirt
down on Lower Mecklenburgh Street,
a kiss for a penny, a pound for a slap.
Sailors, soldiers, gambling sons.
